results.title: ‘Basic Instinct’ at 30: A Time Capsule That Can Still Offend
results.abstract: The erotic thriller starring Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone was a big hit that set off protests in its day, and it’s easy to see why even now.

multimedia.caption: Sharon Stone in the interrogation scene in “Basic Instinct,” which opened on March 20, 1992.
Sharon Stone in the interrogation scene in “Basic Instinct,” which opened on March 20, 1992.
Sharon Stone in the interrogation scene in “Basic Instinct,” which opened on March 20, 1992.

results.title: ‘CODA’ Wins Producers Guild Award, Clearing a Path to Best Picture
results.abstract: The prize is considered the best bellwether for the Oscars, though the Apple TV+ film still faces stiff competition from “The Power of the Dog.”

multimedia.caption: “CODA” cast members Daniel Durant, left, Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin at the Producers Guild Awards.
“CODA” cast members Daniel Durant, left, Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin at the Producers Guild Awards.
“CODA” cast members Daniel Durant, left, Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin at the Producers Guild Awards.

results.title: Oscars Rewind: The Last Time Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg Went Head-to-Head
results.abstract: The filmmakers are nominated for best director this year, just as they were in 1994. Back then, there wasn’t a clear favorite.

multimedia.caption: Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg this month at the AFI Awards Luncheon in Beverly Hills.
Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg this month at the AFI Awards Luncheon in Beverly Hills.
Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg this month at the AFI Awards Luncheon in Beverly Hills.

results.title: A ‘Lost City’ Group Chat With Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum and Daniel Radcliffe
results.abstract: Their movie comedy will be under close scrutiny at the box office. But they aren’t fazed and have lots to say about that Brad Pitt cameo, “Magic Mike” and “Harry Potter.”

multimedia.caption: Tatum, Bullock and Radcliffe say they’re happy that “The Lost City” will be released in theaters but mainly are interested in entertaining audiences no matter the platform.
multimedia.copyright: Amy Harrity for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Tatum, Bullock and Radcliffe say they’re happy that “The Lost City” will be released in theaters but mainly are interested in entertaining audiences no matter the platform.

results.title: In Art and Tennis, Watch Out for the Backhand
results.abstract: Jane Campion’s comment about Venus and Serena Williams reminded our critic of his own night of ‘botched fanciness’ and racial slights.

multimedia.caption: Venus Williams, left, and Serena Williams at the Critics Choice Awards; “King Richard,” a movie about their family, earned a best actor award for Will Smith.
Venus Williams, left, and Serena Williams at the Critics Choice Awards; “King Richard,” a movie about their family, earned a best actor award for Will Smith.
Venus Williams, left, and Serena Williams at the Critics Choice Awards; “King Richard,” a movie about their family, earned a best actor award for Will Smith.

results.title: ‘X’ Review: Trash, Art and the Movies
results.abstract: Ti West’s latest is a slasher film about the making of a porno film, but the result might not be what you expect.

multimedia.caption: Mia Goth in “X,” from the director Ti West, whose inspirations appear to include “The Texas Chainsaw Massacre” and “Debbie Does Dallas.”
Mia Goth in “X,” from the director Ti West, whose inspirations appear to include “The Texas Chainsaw Massacre” and “Debbie Does Dallas.”
Mia Goth in “X,” from the director Ti West, whose inspirations appear to include “The Texas Chainsaw Massacre” and “Debbie Does Dallas.”

results.abstract: For her new sci-fi comedy, the martial-arts star had to attempt a more psychological kind of acrobatics.

results.abstract: Regina Hall anchors this horror movie debut from Mariama Diallo, set on a New England college campus.

results.title: ‘Deep Water’ Review: Love and Loathing in New Orleans
results.abstract: An unhappy husband raises suspicions when his wife’s lovers begin to disappear.

multimedia.caption: Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck in “Deep Water.”
Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck in “Deep Water.”
Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck in “Deep Water.”

results.title: After Criticism, Film Museum Will Highlight Hollywood’s Jewish History
results.abstract: The new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, which tried to present an inclusive history of film, overlooked the role Jewish immigrants played in creating the industry.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: The new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, whch was criticized for overlooking the role Jewish immigrants played in creating the industry, is planning to make up for the omission with a new permanent exhibition next year.
multimedia.copyright: Rozette Rago for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, whch was criticized for overlooking the role Jewish immigrants played in creating the industry, is planning to make up for the omission with a new permanent exhibition next year.

results.title: ‘Atlantide’ Review: Restless and Reckless on the Venetian Lagoon
results.abstract: A speed boater and his girlfriend maneuver around the coasts of Venice and its islands in this moody portrait of contemporary youth culture.

multimedia.caption: Alberto Tedesco in “Atlantide.”
Alberto Tedesco in “Atlantide.”
Alberto Tedesco in “Atlantide.”

results.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Atlanta’ and the Academy Awards
results.abstract: Donald Glover’s series returns for a third season on FX. And the 94th Oscars ceremony airs on ABC.

results.title: Writers Guild Awards Keep Up Momentum for ‘CODA,’ ‘Don’t Look Up’
results.abstract: The victories are good news for those films’ Oscar chances: The best picture winner usually also picks up a screenplay trophy.

multimedia.caption: Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence in “Don’t Look Up,” which won for original screenplay at the WGA Awards.
Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence in “Don’t Look Up,” which won for original screenplay at the WGA Awards.

results.title: Peter Bowles, Actor in ‘To the Manor Born,’ Dies at 85
results.abstract: In a six-decade career in TV, film and onstage, he played comedy and drama, hapless heroes and villains, often with the air of the archetypal English gent.

multimedia.caption: Peter Bowles in “To the Manor Born,” the long-running British comedy series (also shown on PBS) about a nouveau-riche owner of a supermarket who buys a grand English manor house.
multimedia.copyright: Photo by PA Images via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Peter Bowles in “To the Manor Born,” the long-running British comedy series (also shown on PBS) about a nouveau-riche owner of a supermarket who buys a grand English manor house.
multimedia.copyright: Photo by PA Images via Getty Images

multimedia.copyright: Photo by PA Images via Getty Images

results.title: Jack Willis, TV Producer and Empathetic Filmmaker, Dies at 87
results.abstract: A survivor of a crippling accident, his documentaries and news coverage for public television focused on poverty, race and other social issues.

multimedia.caption: Jack Willis im 1971. His commitment to civil rights was reflected in his enduring friendship with the singer and activist Harry Belafonte, who called him “a soul brother.”
multimedia.copyright: Don West Broadcasting & Cable collection, Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries. Photo by L.M. Romano

multimedia.caption: Jack Willis im 1971. His commitment to civil rights was reflected in his enduring friendship with the singer and activist Harry Belafonte, who called him “a soul brother.”
multimedia.copyright: Don West Broadcasting & Cable collection, Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries. Photo by L.M. Romano

results.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include near-future psychological drama, Oscar-nominated robot antics and a bearded, mysterious Hugo Weaving.

multimedia.caption: Hugo Weaving in “Expired.”
Hugo Weaving in “Expired.”
Hugo Weaving in “Expired.”

results.title: ‘Texas Chain Saw Massacre’ and the Lessons Few Horror Films Get Right
results.abstract: Ti West is the rare genre director to understand the original and honor it with a movie, “X,” that also works on its own terms.

multimedia.caption: Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface in the original “Texas Chain Saw Massacre,” which makes us emphathize with a killer even amid the gore.
Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface in the original “Texas Chain Saw Massacre,” which makes us emphathize with a killer even amid the gore.
Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface in the original “Texas Chain Saw Massacre,” which makes us emphathize with a killer even amid the gore.

results.title: ‘Windfall’ Review: Money Talks
results.abstract: A wealthy couple is detained by an incompetent thief in this airless Netflix drama.

multimedia.caption: From left, Jason Segel, Lily Collins and Jesse Plemons in “Windfall.”
From left, Jason Segel, Lily Collins and Jesse Plemons in “Windfall.”
From left, Jason Segel, Lily Collins and Jesse Plemons in “Windfall.”

results.title: ‘Jane by Charlotte’ Review: A Mother-Daughter Duet
results.abstract: Charlotte Gainsbourg makes her directorial debut with an elusive portrait of her mother, the French-English star Jane Birkin, at age 74.

multimedia.caption: Charlotte Gainsbourg with her mother, Jane Birkin, in “Jane by Charlotte.”
Charlotte Gainsbourg with her mother, Jane Birkin, in “Jane by Charlotte.”
Charlotte Gainsbourg with her mother, Jane Birkin, in “Jane by Charlotte.”

results.title: ‘More Than Robots’ Review: An International Battle
results.abstract: Despite the movie’s title, robots are the subject and spectacle of this lighthearted film about a high school robotics competition.

multimedia.caption: A team competes in “More Than Robots,” a documentary directed by Gillian Jacobs.
A team competes in “More Than Robots,” a documentary directed by Gillian Jacobs.
A team competes in “More Than Robots,” a documentary directed by Gillian Jacobs.

results.title: ‘Intregalde’ Review: Oh, Be Good!
results.abstract: A Romanian satire charts what happens when some humanitarian aid workers set out to save others (and need to be saved themselves).

multimedia.caption: A bump in the road to good works: from left, Ilona Brezoianu, Maria Popistasu and Alex Bogdan in “Intregalde.”
A bump in the road to good works: from left, Ilona Brezoianu, Maria Popistasu and Alex Bogdan in “Intregalde.”
A bump in the road to good works: from left, Ilona Brezoianu, Maria Popistasu and Alex Bogdan in “Intregalde.”

results.title: ‘Ahed’s Knee’ Review: A Filmmaker’s Agony in the Desert
results.abstract: Nadav Lapid’s new film, about a brooding director much like himself, is a howl of rage at the state of Israeli society.

multimedia.caption: Avshalom Pollak, left, and Nur Fibak in “Ahed’s Knee.” The actor is a stand-in for the film’s director, Nadav Lapid.
Avshalom Pollak, left, and Nur Fibak in “Ahed’s Knee.” The actor is a stand-in for the film’s director, Nadav Lapid.
Avshalom Pollak, left, and Nur Fibak in “Ahed’s Knee.” The actor is a stand-in for the film’s director, Nadav Lapid.

results.title: ‘Love After Love’ Review: Elegance Without a Center
results.abstract: Ann Hui’s World War II-era film is lovely to look at but lacks emotional depth and resonance.

multimedia.caption: Sandra Ma and Eddie Peng in “Love After Love,” by Ann Hui.
Sandra Ma and Eddie Peng in “Love After Love,” by Ann Hui.
Sandra Ma and Eddie Peng in “Love After Love,” by Ann Hui.

results.title: ‘The Torch’ Review: The Blues Legend Buddy Guy Sows His Legacy
results.abstract: A new documentary by Jim Farrell focuses on the musician’s sense of mission.

multimedia.caption: Buddy Guy with his protégé Quinn Sullivan, in “The Torch.”
Buddy Guy with his protégé Quinn Sullivan, in “The Torch.”
Buddy Guy with his protégé Quinn Sullivan, in “The Torch.”

results.title: ‘Alice’ Review: American Slavery and Black Power Collide
results.abstract: This time-bending thriller about a woman who escapes from slavery in 1973, starring Keke Palmer and Common, is a vapid historical romp.

multimedia.caption: Keke Palmer and Common in “Alice.”
Keke Palmer and Common in “Alice.”
Keke Palmer and Common in “Alice.”

results.title: ‘Panama’ Review: Welcome to the Jungle, We Lack Fun and Games
results.abstract: Mel Gibson drops in from time to time in this predictable throwback thriller from Mark Neveldine.

multimedia.caption: Cole Hauser, left, and Mel Gibson in “Panama.”
Cole Hauser, left, and Mel Gibson in “Panama.”
Cole Hauser, left, and Mel Gibson in “Panama.”

results.title: ‘The Outfit’ Review: The Violent Measure of a Man
results.abstract: In this gangster exercise set in 1956 Chicago, Mark Rylance plays a tailor who has very large scissors and some sharp moves.

multimedia.caption: Mark Rylance in “The Outfit,” directed by Graham Moore.
Mark Rylance in “The Outfit,” directed by Graham Moore.
Mark Rylance in “The Outfit,” directed by Graham Moore.

results.title: The Secret Sounds of ‘Dune’: Rice Krispies and Marianne Faithfull
results.abstract: Denis Villeneuve and his sound team explain how far they went to achieve an aural experience that would feel somewhat familiar, an unusual approach for sci-fi.
results.byline: By Kyle Buchanan and Peter Fisher

multimedia.caption: Working with sand in Death Valley.
Working with sand in Death Valley.
Working with sand in Death Valley.

results.title: Mandy Patinkin Finds Healing in Refugee Work and Praying With His Dog
results.abstract: Right when the actor thought he’d done almost everything, Ken Burns offered him the role of Benjamin Franklin, and, just maybe, held off an early retirement.

results.title: ‘Josep’ Review: Escaping a Civil War
results.abstract: The French cartoonist known as Aurel animates the life of the Catalan illustrator Josep Bartolí, who lived in French internment camps and loved Frida Kahlo.

multimedia.caption: The cartoonist Aurel’s debut feature is a hand-drawn film about the life of the Catalan illustrator Josep Bartolí, who left Spain for France in 1939.
The cartoonist Aurel’s debut feature is a hand-drawn film about the life of the Catalan illustrator Josep Bartolí, who left Spain for France in 1939.
The cartoonist Aurel’s debut feature is a hand-drawn film about the life of the Catalan illustrator Josep Bartolí, who left Spain for France in 1939.

results.title: ‘The Last Mountain’ Review: Impossible Summits
results.abstract: This documentary from Chris Terrill struggles to make emotional sense of its story, involving a mother and a son who both died on climbs.

multimedia.caption: The siblings Tom and Kate Ballard in the documentary “The Last Mountain.”
The siblings Tom and Kate Ballard in the documentary “The Last Mountain.”
The siblings Tom and Kate Ballard in the documentary “The Last Mountain.”

results.title: Jane Campion Apologizes for Comment About Venus and Serena Williams
results.abstract: In an acceptance speech at the Critics Choice Awards, the “Power of the Dog” filmmaker wrongly suggested that the tennis greats didn’t compete against men the way she had to.

multimedia.caption: Jane Campion at the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday.
Jane Campion at the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday.
Jane Campion at the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday.

results.title: Ari Wegner: A Cinematographer Who Knows Actors Down to the Eyelash
results.abstract: The director of photography for “The Power of the Dog” spent a year on preproduction. Now she could make Oscar history as the first woman to win best cinematography.

multimedia.caption: There’s an unusual closeness between cinematographer and actor, Ari Wegner said: “You’re getting to know their face and their body in a way that is so private and intimate.”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: There’s an unusual closeness between cinematographer and actor, Ari Wegner said: “You’re getting to know their face and their body in a way that is so private and intimate.”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
